actions-list.actionItem: The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 3317.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Molinaro moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 3317 — "To amend title 49, United States Code, to remove the lifetime exemption from the prohibition on procurement of rolling stock from certain vehicle manufacturers for parties to executed contracts."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 5863.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Smith (MO) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 5863 — "To provide tax relief with respect to certain Federal disasters."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1097.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. McHenry moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1097 — "To award a Congressional Gold Medal to Everett Alvarez, Jr., in recognition of his service to the Nation."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 807.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. McHenry moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 807 — "To require the Secretary of the Treasury to mint coins in commemoration of the invaluable service that working dogs provide to society."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 3019.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Ms. Mace moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 3019 — "To establish an inspections regime for the Bureau of Prisons, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 5887.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Ms. Mace moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 5887 — "To amend chapter 3 of title 5, United States Code, to improve Government service delivery, and build related capacity for the Federal Government, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 5527.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Ms. Mace moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 5527 — "To amend section 1078 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2018 to increase the effectiveness of the Technology Modernization Fund, and for other purposes."
The Speaker announced that votes on suspensions, if ordered, will be postponed until a time to be announced.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of May 21.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.

actions-list.header: Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to Senate Concurrent Resolution 34, 118th Congress, and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed the following members of the House to the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies: Mr. Johnson of Louisiana, Mr. Scalise and Mr. Jeffries.

actions-list.header: The Speaker laid before the House a message from the President transmitting a notification stating that the national emergency with respect to the stabilization of Iraq declared in Executive Order 13303 of May 22, 2023, as modified by Executive Order 13290 of March 20, 2003, Executive Order 13315 of August 28, 2003, Executive Order 13350 of July 29, 2004, Executive Order 13364 of November 29, 2004, Executive Order 13438 of July 17, 2007, and Executive Order 13668 of May 27, 2014, is to continue in effect beyond May 22, 2024.
actions-list.actionItem: referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs and ordered to be printed (H. Doc. 118-143).

The House received a message from the Acting Clerk. Pursuant to the permission granted in Clause 2(h) of Rule II of the Rules of the U.S. House of Representatives, the Acting Clerk transmitted a sealed envelope received from the White House on May 20, 2024, at 3:07 p.m., said to contain a message from the President regarding the Continuation of the National Emergency With Respect to the Stabilization of Iraq.

The House received a message from the Acting Clerk. Pursuant to the permission granted in Clause 2(h) of Rule II of the Rules of the U.S. House of Representatives, the Acting Clerk received the following message from the Secretary of the Senate on May 20, 2024, at 1:55 p.m.: That the Senate passed H.J. Res. 109. Appointment: United States Commission on International Religious Freedom.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches.
The Chair designated Mr. Thompson of PA to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal. Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of May 21.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 2:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 2:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable David Kustoff to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
